On the Imperial Fora at Rome, see Anderson 1984; also Gros 1996: 216–20, and 220–9 on their influence on Roman cities outside Italy

The most extensive treatment of the battered evidence from the forum at Arles is Gros 1987, who proposes radical rethinking of the dating and implications of the remains (in particular hypothesizing the forum adiectum and assigning it to Tiberius), sometimes following suggestions made by Gladiss 1972; see also Gros 2008: 40–50, esp. figs. 26 and 32, and 2009: esp. 113; the dating to Tiberius is open to question. For the more traditional view, see Grenier 1958: 291–308 and 321–2, who is followed by Rivet 1988: 193–4, and Bromwich 1996: 144–6. Perhaps most satisfactory of all is to accept Gros’ suggestion of a forum adiectum, but to observe that its architectural form and placement both suggest Imperial forum architecture much more likely to date from the time of Trajan or later than that of Tiberius
The evidence, such as it is, is neatly summarized in Darde and LaSalle 1993
